descriptionLinks: Calculate Reaction Profile Using the Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) method with VASP: https://docs.exabyte.io/tutorials/dft/chemical/reaction-profile-vasp/
description: In this tutorial, we explain how to calculate the energy reaction profile and activation barrier for the multi-dimensional energy space of chemical reactions via the Nudged Elastic Bands (NEB) method, by making use of the VASP simulation engine coupled with a manually-generated interpolated set.
title: Exabyte.io Tutorial: NEB Reaction Profile using VASP

youTubeCaptions.text: Calculate Reaction Energy Profile tutorial.
Create a simulation, by navigating to the job designer page.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> open the materials tab, and choose the entire Interpolated Set by selecting all five images of the hydrogen molecule in the example list.

Then, <break time='0.5' /> open the workflow tab, and choose the 'Nudged Elastic Band' workflow by selecting it in the list. <break time='0.5' /> This workflow can be imported from the bank, if it is not already listed.

Now, let us examine the first subworkflow, for calculating the total energy of the initial and final images in the interpolated set. Open the first <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> unit for the initial structure calculation, by clicking it.
Inspect the <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> input files displayed at the bottom. They are used to perform a basic total energy ground state SCF calculation.
The same input parameters can be retrieved in the second <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> unit, for the final structure calculation.

We now navigate to the 'Important Settings' tab, where we set the size of the grid of k-points to one for both the initial and final image structures, since we are dealing with chemical molecules in this case.

Next, we inspect the contents of the second subworkflow. <break time='1.0' /> It is used to run a shell script, which prepares the directories necessary to run a <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> N.E.B. calculation.

The outputs of the previous subworkflow, on the SCF calculations applied to the initial and final images, are here copied into the initial <sub alias='zero zero'>(00)</sub> and final (0N) directories, respectively. <break time='1.0' /> The remaining intermediate images are put in <sub alias='zero one'>(01)</sub> to <sub alias='zero n minus one'>'0(N-1)'</sub> directories.
Finally, we look at the main N.E.B. subworkflow, and inspect its only unit.

Within the <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> input script at the bottom, pay particular attention to the 'IMAGES' input parameter, defining the number of interpolated image geometries between the initial and final states. <break time='1.0' /> Also, the 'SPRING' keyword defines the spring constant between the images. <break time='1.0' /> A negative value turns on nudging.
Once again, under the 'Important Settings' tab, we set the size of the grid of k-points to one, for all intermediate images as well.

After that, <break time='0.5' /> navigate to compute tab, and set compute configuration. Here, we use one node with six cores on the OR8 queue, since for <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> N.E.B. calculations the number of cores has to be a multiple of the number of intermediate images, which in our case is three.
For the first initial/final total energy subworkflow, six cores are not necessary, and hence we set a separate compute configuration with four cores only.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> set the name for the job. <break time='2.0' /> Here, we call it - <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> N.E.B. Reaction Profile Calculation.
Next, <break time='0.5' /> save the job. <break time='5.0' /> It can then be selected and submitted to the compute queue, for execution. <break time='4.0' />
The status of the calculation will change from pre-submitted to submitted, and then to active.
When the job is finished, open it, to inspect the final results.

The final result for the plot of the reaction energy profile, as a function of the overall reaction coordinate, can be found towards the bottom of the results page. <break time='1.0' /> The correct activation energy barrier for the collinear proton transfer reaction in hydrogen, of around 0.2 eV, has therefore been computed, as expected.
This completes the present tutorial.
